H0.text: Ozone thinning is the environmental problem that would most likely be reduced by the use of nuclear fuel.

H1.text: Landfill creation is the environmental problem that use of nuclear fuel would most likely reduce human contributions to.

H2.text: Shoreline erosion is the environmental problem that would most likely be reduced by using nuclear fuel, thereby lessening human contributions.

H3.text: Greenhouse heating is the environmental problem whose human contributions would most likely be reduced by the use of nuclear fuel.

A4.text: In 2014, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change reported that the median life‑cycle emission intensity of nuclear power was 12 g CO₂eq/kWh, the lowest among all commercial baseload energy sources.

A5.text: As of 2021, nuclear reactors worldwide have helped avoid the emission of 72 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide since 1970, compared to coal‑fired electricity generation.
